skill.name: simpy

Use this skill when building simulations of systems with processes, queues, resources, and time-based events such as manufacturing systems, service operations, network traffic, logistics, or any system where entities interact with shared resources over time.

security_audit.summary: Static analysis flagged 260 potential security issues, but evaluation confirms all are false positives. The 'external_commands' findings are markdown backticks used for code formatting, not shell execution. The 'weak cryptographic algorithm' flags refer to random.seed() for simulation reproducibility. No actual security risks exist in this legitimate SimPy discrete-event simulation skill.

content.value_statement: SimPy enables you to model complex systems with processes, queues, and shared resources. Simulate manufacturing lines, service operations, network traffic, and logistics to optimize performance before implementation.
actual_capabilities: Create process-based simulations with Python generator functions
Model resource contention and queueing behavior with multiple resource types
Monitor utilization, wait times, and throughput with built-in tracking
Generate reusable simulation templates for common patterns
Export results to CSV for external analysis
Simulate real-time systems synchronized with wall-clock time
limitations: Not suitable for continuous simulations with fixed time steps
Requires Python generator functions for process definition
Large-scale models may have performance constraints

prompt_templates.title: Basic Queue Simulation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a SimPy simulation of customers arriving at a bank with 2 tellers. Customers arrive every 3-5 minutes and service takes 5-8 minutes. Run for 8 hours and show average wait time.

prompt_templates.title: Manufacturing Line
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a SimPy model of a 3-stage manufacturing line where parts go through cutting (10 min), assembly (15 min), and inspection (5 min). Each stage has 1 machine. Analyze throughput.

prompt_templates.title: Network Packet Simulation
prompt_templates.prompt: Simulate packets arriving at a router with 100 Mbps bandwidth. Packets are 1-5 KB and arrive at 50 packets per second. Show queue length and packet loss under peak load.

prompt_templates.title: Resource Optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Model a cloud data center with 10 servers handling 3 types of jobs: short (1-5 min), medium (10-20 min), long (30-60 min). Jobs arrive randomly. Find optimal server allocation per job type.

best_practices: Always use context managers (with statement) when requesting resources to ensure proper cleanup and prevent deadlocks
Set random.seed() for reproducible results when comparing different simulation scenarios
Monitor and collect data throughout the simulation, not just at the end, to capture transient behavior
anti_patterns: Forgetting yield statements in process functions will cause processes to run instantly without proper timing
Reusing events that have already been triggered will cause simulation errors or unexpected behavior
Using blocking Python operations like time.sleep() instead of env.timeout() breaks the simulation timing model

faq.question: What is the difference between Environment and RealtimeEnvironment?
faq.answer: Environment runs simulations as fast as possible, while RealtimeEnvironment synchronizes simulation time with wall-clock time for real-time or hardware-in-the-loop applications.

faq.question: How do I choose the right resource type for my simulation?
faq.answer: Use Resource for basic capacity limits, PriorityResource for priority queuing, Container for bulk materials like fuel or water, and Store for object storage with FIFO or filtering.

faq.question: Can I interrupt a running process in SimPy?
faq.answer: Yes, use process.interrupt() to forcefully resume a paused process. This is useful for modeling preemption, timeouts, or external cancellation events.

faq.question: How do I collect custom statistics during a simulation?
faq.answer: Use the ResourceMonitor class from the provided scripts or create custom monitors by patching resource methods and tracking events during simulation execution.

faq.question: What is the best way to model parallel processes that need synchronization?
faq.answer: Start multiple processes with env.process() and use the yield operator with & operator to wait for all processes to complete, or | for any process completion.

faq.question: How can I export simulation results for external analysis?
faq.answer: Use the export_csv() method in ResourceMonitor to save collected data, or write custom export functions using the data dictionaries tracked during simulation.
